item.title: Anthony is an 84-year-old grandfather who has spent 30 years...
item.content:encoded:
Colorado Attorneys Against Police Violence

Anthony is an 84-year-old grandfather who has spent 30 years incarcerated for a series of robberies and spends each day confined in a wheelchair in his cell in Sterling, terrified of catching COVID-19.

‚ÄúI fear the way the COVID-19 has ravaged this facility. It has put a great deal of us at-risk adult in harms way. For me, this can be a potential death sentence. At my age and with underlying health conditions, this feels like cruel and unusual punishment.‚Äù

‚Äî Anthony Martinez...

Anthony Martinez is an 84-year-old grandfather suffering from renal failure, as well as other serious medical conditions including dementia. He is currently incarcerated in the Sterling Correctional Facility, site of one of Colorado‚Äôs largest COVID-19 outbreaks with almost 600 active COVID-19 cases. He and his family are understandably terrified that he will catch the virus and die.

Anthony has spent over 30 years behind bars for a series of robberies. He has paid a substantial debt to society for these crimes. With his age and infirmity, no one can argue he is a public safety risk, but he has a substantial risk of becoming seriously ill or dying from COVID-19 if he remains incarcerated. Despite this, his special needs parole application was denied.

Anthony‚Äôs niece, Kelly, has a room in her home waiting for him to spend his final years. She says, ‚ÄúOnly nine people on the side of the prison where my uncle is currently held are still negative for COVID-19. It‚Äôs all around him and it‚Äôs only a matter of time before he gets sick. I know my uncle is lonely and isolated. He uses a wheelchair, is hard of hearing and is locked in his cell almost all day. Prison is no place for elderly people. Please, I need my uncle home before he dies.‚Äù

In the midst of this public health crisis, incarcerated people as vulnerable as Anthony, could and should be immediately released to safely live out their remaining years with family. #decarcerationday #FreeThemAll #covidjustice #carenotcages #endmassincarceration #COVIDcolorado #doyourpart #bringourneighborshome #redemptionisreal #clemencyiscompassion

item.title: Ronald Johnson is pre-diabetic, suffers from asthma and high...
item.content:encoded:
ACLU of Colorado

Ronald Johnson is pre-diabetic, suffers from asthma and high blood pressure, and regularly uses an inhaler to breathe. His age and respiratory ailments put him at risk of serious illness and death if he contracts COVID-19. With over hundreds of active cases in Colorado‚Äôs prisons, his family fears he will not make it out alive. His daughter, Amber, says, ‚ÄúIn prison, he can‚Äôt protect himself and he can‚Äôt social distance. My deep fear is that my dad will die in prison. That is a...n awful, traumatic reality to consider. My chest is tight just thinking about how quickly it spreads and how vulnerable he is.‚Äù

Governor Hickenlooper shortened his sentence following testimony from family, friends and correctional officers advocating for his early release. Yet, he is still eight years away from parole. While he remains in prison, COVID-19 continues to spread. Ronald‚Äôs three siblings, four children and four grandchildren are desperate for his release.

item.title: ‚ÄºÔ∏èToday is the day‚ÄºÔ∏è Come stand with us on the steps of...
item.content:encoded:
Colorado Attorneys Against Police Violence

‚ÄºÔ∏èToday is the day‚ÄºÔ∏è

Come stand with us on the steps of the People‚Äôs House and tell @govofco to stop fear mongering about the human beings - who are disproportionately Black, Brown, and Indigenous - languishing in Colorado ages, some never having been convicted of a crime. Stand with us while we tell @govofco that the people he is painting as ‚Äúdangerous criminals‚Äù are human beings who don‚Äôt deserve to die. Stand with him while we tell him that compassionate release of the vul...nerable, the elderly, non-dangerous, and the non-convicted is an easy choice, and that if he wants us to be ‚Äúsafer at home,‚Äù that must include *all* Coloradans, and not just the ones who look like him.

And thanks to our friends at Party for Socialism and Liberation - Denver for making this rad flyer and standing with us!

#CAAPV #Decarcerate

item.title: Abolish ICE DenverCommunity E(Check the down below or comments section for sources)‚Äº‚Äº‚Äº Even before the tragedy that happened last...
item.content:encoded:
Abolish ICE DenverCommunity E

(Check the down below or comments section for sources)‚Äº‚Äº‚Äº

Even before the tragedy that happened last night there were reports of Police departments that were PU...RPOSELY allowing right-wing supremacist to brutalize BLM protestors as a way of sending a message.
The cops can do this because they know that qualified immunity prevents them from being sued for their negligence. If they encourage violence and someone gets hurt, like with last night, THEY can always avoid being sued for their misconduct.
But it doesn't have to be like this. There is a bill currently in the US House of Representative that would remove Q.I. It won't end racism and corruption in our government, but it's a start to accountability. We NEED you to demand your Congress representatives to get this passed. Links to help you will be provided in the comments, but please share this post.

1) https://www.huffpost.com/‚Ä¶/portland-police-far-right-proud-‚Ä¶

2) https://www.congress.gov/bill/116th-congress/house-bill/7085

3) https://www.house.gov/representa.../find-your-representative

4) https://www.senate.gov/.../contact.../senators_cfm.cfm

item.title: 100 People without Housing Swept to Nowhere Today: Disabled Vet...
item.content:encoded:
Denver Homeless Out Loud

100 People without Housing Swept to Nowhere Today: Disabled Vet Stands His Ground; Voices of Residents Must be Heard

Today, Wednesday August 26th, the city came back again at 5am to sweep away about 100 people from where many of them had been staying for months. Residents of this area were specifically told by police they did not know where they could move to. At least off camera they admitted the truth!@# Many people were in tears and turmoil trying to figure out where to mo...ve after the sweep. A couple people were given one or two night hotel vouchers...and than they will be back on the streets dealing with the same search for where to stay as they await housing to be made attainable.
3.jpg

Four protesters were arrested after being in the street briefly trying to film the situation. Police bumrushed them, brutally hurting at least two of them, and arresting 4 people simply for being in the street for a short time, most not even blocking traffic. A few minutes later, people were standing in the street doing the exact same thing right in front of police and none of them were arrested. Yet another example why money to fund police should be used on housing and resources, not police.

Hear the voices from the street.
Words from the Street...Before August 26th Sweep

"'It‚Äôs very stressful, this constant moving. "
"They are complicating our survival."
"We have a right to be here, we have a right not to go to the shelter with bed bugs."
"Fuck the Puereos"
"It makes me feel good that people care and are helping."
"I have no where to go."
"We are not cattle."
"Until they offer me a home, I will be in this spot with my tent."
"This is where my case manager can find me, my path to housing."
"Give me one logical reason why I have to move."
"The only way I will move my stuff is if they hand me a lease to an apartment. "

Contact:
info@denverhomelessoutloud.org
720-940-5291

See More
item.author: Denver Homeless Out Loud

Denver Homeless Out Loud

100 People without Housing Swept to Nowhere Today: Disabled Vet Stands His Ground; Voices of Residents Must be Heard

Today, Wednesday August 26th, the city came back again at 5am to sweep away about 100 people from where many of them had been staying for months. Residents of this area were specifically told by police they did not know where they could move to. At least off camera they admitted the truth!@# Many people were in tears and turmoil trying to figure out where to mo...ve after the sweep. A couple people were given one or two night hotel vouchers...and than they will be back on the streets dealing with the same search for where to stay as they await housing to be made attainable.

Four protesters were arrested after being in the street briefly trying to film the situation. Police bumrushed them, brutally hurting at least two of them, and arresting 4 people simply for being in the street for a short time, most not even blocking traffic. A few minutes later, people were standing in the street doing the exact same thing right in front of police and none of them were arrested. Yet another example why money to fund police should be used on housing and resources, not police.

Hear the voices from the street.

Words from the Street...Before August 26th Sweep

It‚Äôs very stressful, this constant moving.

They are complicating our survival.

We have a right to be here, we have a right not to go to the shelter with bed bugs.

Fuck the Puereos

It makes me feel good that people care and are helping.

I have no where to go.

We are not cattle.

Until they offer me a home, I will be in this spot with my tent.

This is where my case manager can find me, my path to housing.

Give me one logical reason why I have to move.

The only way I will move my stuff is if they hand me a lease to an apartment.

item.title: The plight of people behind bars in the U.S. during the...
item.content:encoded:
Party for Socialism and Liberation - Denver

The plight of people behind bars in the U.S. during the coronavirus pandemic is dire. Prisoners and detainees are getting sick and dying at highly elevated rates, and without immediate and sweeping action, mass deaths‚Äîdisproportionately of poor, Black, Brown, and Indigenous people‚Äîare a certainty. This is why PSL Denver is backing tomorrow‚Äôs Decarceration Day of Action, organized by the Colorado ACLU and endorsed by more than 50 local organizations.

Join the rally at noon tomorrow at the capitol, and demand Governor Polis immediately release all elderly, vulnerable, non-dangerous, and non-convicted inmates and all ICE detainees!
item.author: Party for Socialism and Liberation

item.title: The plight of people behind bars in the U.S. during the...
item.content:encoded:
Party for Socialism and Liberation - Denver

The plight of people behind bars in the U.S. during the coronavirus pandemic is dire. Prisoners and detainees are getting sick and dying at highly elevated rates, and without immediate and sweeping action, mass deaths‚Äîdisproportionately of poor, Black, Brown, and Indigenous people‚Äîare a certainty. This is why PSL Denver is backing tomorrow‚Äôs Decarceration Day of Action. Join the rally at noon tomorrow at the capitol and read Dr. Apryl Alexander‚Äôs opinion piece on the day of a...ction in the Denver Post.

‚ÄúAfter briefly allowing increased prisoner releases, the governor has rescinded that authority and refuses to exercise any of his broad powers to safely reduce the prison population.

Surely, the governor is aware that the United States incarcerates people at a higher rate than any other country in the world, and that mass incarceration has destroyed Black communities, without improving public safety. Surely he is aware that our carceral system is founded on racist principles, and the racial make-up of our prisons is a reflection of historical and ongoing systemic racism.

Yet, rather than acknowledging the humanity of people living behind bars and the racism underlying the prison system, Gov. Polis has contributed to a public narrative that demonizes incarcerated people as unredeemable and too dangerous to be free. When advocates called for thoughtful releases of vulnerable incarcerated people, Gov. Polis‚Äô response: He would not ‚Äúlet dangerous criminals out.‚Äù

Come on, governor. No one wants you to release ‚Äúdangerous criminals.‚Äù We all want to be safe. That‚Äôs why advocates have been calling for the release of people who are elderly, sick, or have otherwise proven they are not a public safety threat. Decades of mass incarceration has ensured that there are many such people in Colorado‚Äôs prisons, and racism has ensured that those people will be disproportionately Black.

Here‚Äôs just one example: Ron Johnson is a 62-year-old Black grandfather who has turned his life around in prison. He suffers from asthma, high blood pressure, and uses an inhaler to breathe, so he is at high risk for COVID. He is no threat to the public. He lives in an incentive unit where he cares for other incarcerated people with medical disabilities and mentors incarcerated people earning their GED.‚Äù

See MoreBlack people living behind bars face a racist double whammy ‚Äì because of their blackness they are more likely to be imprisoned, more likely to get COVID, and more likely to die from the virus.

denverpost.com

Guest commentary: If Black lives matter to him, Polis needs to reduce prison population

Party for Socialism and Liberation - Denver

Cops and the Klan go hand-in-hand. WATCH THIS CLIP! This footage was taken 15 minutes before the Kenosha shooter Kyle Rittenhouse murdered two anti-racist protesters and injured a third. The cops offer the armed white supremacist vigilantes water (Rittenhouse is the one walking over to get water), and thank them for what they are doing. At the very same time, they are ordering protesters to clear the streets. 15 minutes later Kyle Rittenhouse shot 3 protesters, gave a hand si...gn to the cops, and walked right past 3 police vehicles without even being stopped.

As the system tries to clamp down on the anti-racist uprising sweeping the country, the police keep further exposing that they are not an institution with the purpose of protecting our communities, but a violent repressive force dedicated to upholding a white supremacist order. They will join forces with openly racist elements of the population who will aid them in accomplishing this task.

The anti-racist uprising of people in this country is a real threat to white supremacy, and this country‚Äôs rulers know it! Keep up the fight!

item.title: The history of Black August involves advocacy for Black people...
item.content:encoded:
Black Lives Matter 5280

The history of Black August involves advocacy for Black people who are incarcerated due to the prison industrial complex and political activism for Black people. We continue to in this movement as Black people are both overrepresented in terms of cases of COVID-19 and in correctional settings. This week we are partnering with ACLU of Colorado and Colorado Attorneys Against Police Violence (CAAPV) to demand decarceration.

"A prison sentence should not be a death sentence, but... that is precisely the fate that our panelists fear for their loved ones. Among others, hear from Amber Johnson, the daughter of Ronald Johnson. Mr. Johnson is a 62-year-old grandfather who relies on an inhaler to breathe. He has turned his life around in prison after being convicted of non-violent offenses related to substance abuse, but he is still years away from release.

Panelists will also include attorneys involved in the lawsuit against the Colorado Department of Corrections and Governor Polis for their failure to protect our vulnerable, incarcerated neighbors from COVID-19. There are hundreds of medically vulnerable, sick or elderly prisoners who pose no threat to public safety, but who face a serious risk of dying of COVID-19 in Colorado‚Äôs overcrowded prisons. Join us to decarcerate and save lives."

https://www.facebook.com/acluofcolorado/posts/3478847435482054

See More

WED, AUG 26

Covid-19 Decarceration Panel

Online EventCauses ¬∑ 155 people

item.content:encoded:
Party for Socialism and Liberation - Denver

In response to the COVID-19 pandemic, Quierza Lewis began organizing as inmates were dying, guards were without protective equipment and social distancing an impossibility in an overcrowded prison ‚Äî especially Angola the largest maximum-security prison in the United States.

Since his email communications with outside organizers were discovered by officials, Quierza has been placed in administrative segregation‚Äìsolitary. Two other inmates who were also in communication with th...e same activist were not targeted by the prison system.

When the prison system moved to place Quierza in solitary in May there were already eight COVID-19 deaths among inmates with life sentences in Angola.

item.title: ‚ÄúWho is Ishmael Salaam to you? Many may have their own...
item.content:encoded:
Black Lives Matter 5280

‚ÄúWho is Ishmael Salaam to you? Many may have their own opinions and perceptions of who he really is. To me this man is a survivor, brother, father, and role model! How could one person endure so many battles and still stand tall ready to fight whatever comes their way? At 12-13 I struggled being home with my mom due to financial disadvantages leaving me and my sister with nowhere to go or no one to turn to. Ishmael stepped in with the little he had to offer us and made the be...st of it. He made sure he picked us up whenever he felt we tried to slack off by uplifting us with his goofy ways, picking us up and dropping us off at school, and even feeding us when he could barely feed himself. Fast forward years later to him becoming a man and having a beautiful daughter named Ishanti. For a couple of years of her life he was away, but the way he stepped up as a father was not shocking to me I knew his capabilities and god knew them as well. Second time around god blesses him again with another beautiful baby girl Isharri and as he tries his hardest to do right the enemy just couldn't help trying to assassinate his character. Ishmael Salaam was then arrested and convicted life without the possibility of parole plus 100 years for a incident he did not oversee nor was he there. Gwinnett county sentenced him without the proper evidence to prosecute him for this incident! How can our black men rise when society continues to paint our men out as monsters ? How can they sentence pedophiles, molesters, rapists, and kidnappers less time with the eligibility of parole? The system is designed to break up our homes leaving single mothers alone to raise kids on their own. It makes it harder for the people who want to do right and have a second chance at life to even find jobs. Months down the line August 20th, 2020 Ishmael lost the mother of his kids to a battle most people fight on the daily known as "Depression". Mashelle committed suicide leaving their kids without the comfort of a Mothers touch or a Father's touch. They need their father more than we can imagine regardless of who is actually there with them right now no one can fill that void or their hurt like he can. SO AGAIN who is Ishmael salaam to me ? ISHMAEL is a King, a survivor, a father, a brother, a grandson, a hero to some, a shadow, a soldier, a giver, a fighter, and a courageous BLACK MAN . PLEASE help me to help him get home to his kids !! If we stand for nothing we are able to fall for anything.‚Äù #blackinmatesmatter

item.title: A jail or prison sentence should not be a death sentence. Dr....
item.content:encoded:
Colorado Attorneys Against Police Violence

A jail or prison sentence should not be a death sentence. Dr. Alexander, who will be speaking at #CAAPV's Decarceration Day of Action nails it.

"Surely, the governor is aware that the United States incarcerates people at a higher rate than any other country in the world, and that mass incarceration has destroyed Black communities, without improving public safety. Surely he is aware that our carceral system is founded on racist principles, and the racial make-up of our prison...s is a reflection of historical and ongoing systemic racism.

Yet, rather than acknowledging the humanity of people living behind bars and the racism underlying the prison system, Gov. Polis has contributed to a public narrative that demonizes incarcerated people as unredeemable and too dangerous to be free. When advocates called for thoughtful releases of vulnerable incarcerated people, Gov. Polis‚Äô response: He would not ‚Äúlet dangerous criminals out.‚Äù

Come on, governor. No one wants you to release ‚Äúdangerous criminals.‚Äù We all want to be safe. That‚Äôs why advocates have been calling for the release of people who are elderly, sick, or have otherwise proven they are not a public safety threat. Decades of mass incarceration has ensured that there are many such people in Colorado‚Äôs prisons, and racism has ensured that those people will be disproportionately Black."

https://www.denverpost.com/‚Ä¶/colorado-prison-inmates-covid‚Ä¶/

See MoreBlack people living behind bars face a racist double whammy ‚Äì because of their blackness they are more likely to be imprisoned, more likely to get COVID, and more likely to die from the virus.

denverpost.com

Guest commentary: If Black lives matter to him, Polis needs to reduce prison population

item.content:encoded:
Representative Leslie Herod

‚ÄúProtesters gathered in Denver Monday night hoping to draw attention to the police shooting of Jacob Blake in Wisconsin on Sunday.

Cellphone footage posted on social media Sunday appeared to show police shooting Blake multiple times in the back as he opened a door and leaned into an SUV. The state Department of Justice said officers were responding to a domestic incident, but it has not released more details. Blake was in serious condition Monday at a Milwaukee hospital.‚Äù

9NEWS (KUSA)

Jacob Blake was shot multiple times by police over the weekend. He is in serious condition.

9news.com

item.title: As thousands of people again descend on Washington DC to...
item.content:encoded:
Black Lives Matter 5280

As thousands of people again descend on Washington DC to commemorate the March on Washington, #BlackLivesMatterDC is holding space for the families of those killed by state violence in the DC area. These loved ones are too often erased, forgotten and unknown and as a result not uplifted during national actions held here in DC. As part of our Black August events, we are bringing together the families of Black lives taken by the state during this virtual vigil.

A small group of... family members will come together in person for this very special vigil. We know that the Black community particularly in DC has been disproportionately impacted by COVID-19. Therefore we are limiting the in-person attendees and are excited that the vigil will be live streamed. In this way, thousands of people will be able to send their love and support to these families by uplifting the names of their loved ones. We will be live streaming from our Facebook page and we will update people closer to the event on the other ways to watch.

RSVP to receive updates about how you can volunteer and/or watch. https://tinyurl.com/DC-ANCESTORS

#NANMOW2020 #BlackLivesMatter #BlackLivesMatterDC #BlackLivesMatter #DCProtests #DCProtestors #AncestorsWatching #StopMPD #DefundMPD #DefundDCPolice #DefundDCPolice #DefundDPD #DefundAPD #DEFUNDPOLICE #DEFENDBLACKLIFE

See More

THU, AUG 27 AT 6:30 PM EDT

Ancestors Watching Vigil for Black Lives Lost to State Violence

item.title: #CAAPV! Join ACLU of Colorado's COVID-19 Decarceration...
item.content:encoded:
Colorado Attorneys Against Police Violence

#CAAPV! Join ACLU of Colorado's COVID-19 Decarceration Panel to gear up for #DecarcerationDay. Event begins on *tomorrow* August 26, at 4 pm.

Link to RSVP to webinar is here: https://go.peoplepower.org/event/action/22543‚Ä¶

Panelists include: ...
Amber Johnson, whose 62-year-old father, Ronald, has turned his life around in prison after being convicted of non-violent offenses related to substance abuse.

Will Cranfill, whose incarcerated father, James, is a 62-year-old grandfather, artist and Navy veteran who suffers from chronic inflammatory lung disease, a condition that puts him at grave risk of serious illness and death from COVID-19.

Sandra Winston, whose husband, Gary, is a 58-year-old grandfather with severe respiratory problems serving a one-year sentence for drug possession at Sterling, the site of Colorado‚Äôs largest COVID-19 outbreak.

Hassan Latif is the Executive Director and Founder of the Second Chance Center, where he works with justice involved men and women to lead lives of success and fulfillment. The Second Chance Center offers case management, mentoring, and vital resources to assist formerly incarcerated individuals in reestablishing their lives and becoming successful members of the community.

Erica Grossman is a partner in the law firm of Holland, Holland Edwards & Grossman. Erica has litigated a number of cases involving police brutality, unconstitutional jail conditions, first amendment issues, discrimination, and retaliation. She is the ACLU-CO‚Äôs cooperating counsel in the lawsuit against the Colorado Department of Corrections and the Governor for their failure to protect our vulnerable, incarcerated neighbors from COVID-19.

Gail Johnson has more than two decades of experience representing clients in criminal and civil cases in federal and state courts in Colorado, California, and the District of Columbia. You can read about several of Gail‚Äôs clients incarcerated in CDOC with serious underlying medical conditions, including Demika Rogers, Chris Nye and Gary Winston, here: https://aclu-co.org/no-one-deserves-to-die-from-covid-19/

See MoreWe're organizing grassroots volunteers to fight for civil rights and liberties.

go.peoplepower.org

COVID-19 Decarceration Panel | PeoplePower.org

We're organizing grassroots volunteers to fight for civil rights and liberties.We're organizing grassroots volunteers to fight for civil rights and liberties.

Herod said her concern is medics acting outside of policy without repercussions for their actions.

‚ÄúThat needs to change,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúSo we will be looking at and addressing the use of ketamine in Colorado and hopefully we will have bipartisan and a broad base of support to move the effort for...ward.‚Äù

For US policy-makers, Latin America is not an aggregation of sovereign nations but a large lump of subordinated states constituting ‚ÄúAmerica‚Äôs backyard‚Äù. Consequently, this conceptualization of Latin America as a natural extension of the American empire has led to viewing the engagement of any South American country with China, Russia and Iran as a ‚Äúthreat‚Äù to peace and security.

item.title: ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt want anybody to be surprised in our state when...
item.content:encoded:
Representative Leslie Herod

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt want anybody to be surprised in our state when classes, and even schools, do need to be shut down,‚Äù Polis said last week after visiting an elementary school in Aurora that has welcomed students back. ‚ÄúSchools are part of our society. They‚Äôre an important part of our society, but they‚Äôre not some exception to the rule that somehow is immune to what every other part of a society has to have.‚Äù

The Colorado Sun

Without a uniform state policy, it has been left up to Colorado‚Äôs 178 school districts to decide how to proceed during coronavirus. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt want anybody to be surprised in our state when classes, and even schools, do need to be shut down,‚Äù Gov. Jared Polis said last week.

coloradosun.com

item.title: Did you know that deportation proceedings are one of the only...
item.content:encoded:
ACLU of Colorado

Did you know that deportation proceedings are one of the only court cases in the country where a respondent doesn‚Äôt automatically have the right to a public defender? And, people are 10 times more likely to succeed in their immigration case when they have representation?

The Denver Legal Defense fund was created to help provide legal services to those facing deportation. On August 25th, the Vera Institute will be joined by RMIAN, the Denver Foundation, and Mayor Hancock to celebrate and raise awareness for the fund ‚Äî which is critical during times of uncertainty.

item.title: Peace and blessings, family. Securing justice for our communities is critical. Still, we must never normalize watching...
item.content:encoded: Peace and blessings, family. Securing justice for our communities is critical. Still, we must never normalize watching and reading about any violence enacted on our friends and loved ones, pieces of ourselves, on the internet. We give thanks to the ancestors and higher power that guided #JacobBlake back to share more joyful moments with his children like the one in this picture we are intentionally sharing instead of that horrific video. Today we are reminded that it is an essential component of #Blackliberation to take pause and hold space for our whole selves —body, mind, and spirit. To choose healing. #Blackhealingisrevolutionary #BlackLivesMatter

item.title: ‚ÄúBut as McClain‚Äôs story spread outside of Colorado, the...
item.content:encoded:
Representative Leslie Herod

‚ÄúBut as McClain‚Äôs story spread outside of Colorado, the world learned bits and pieces about the person behind the name. That he was an animal lover who didn‚Äôt eat meat, a massage therapist, a self-professed introvert. He was a self-taught violinist who played for cats in animal shelters. He‚Äôs been described by people who knew him as a kind and gentle person, traits that were evident even in his last moments. His story has inspired string players across the country to stage candlelight violin vigils in his honor. And it‚Äôs moved countless creatives like Gordon to create tributes to McClain.‚Äù

Denverite

We spoke to 14 artists from all over the world, from Missouri to New Zealand, about the pieces they created to honor McClain.

denverite.com

A year after Elijah McClain‚Äôs encounter with Aurora police, artists around the world are still telling his story

item.title: Showing Up for Racial Justice - SURJ DenverAlly HennyPenitential whiteness. When white folks go over the top to show how down for the cause...
item.content:encoded:
Showing Up for Racial Justice - SURJ DenverAlly Henny

Penitential whiteness.

When white folks go over the top to show how down for the cause they are. I‚Äôm not talking about it‚Äôs close cousin white guilt. Penitenti...al whiteness differs from white guilt in that it is vocal. It‚Äôs more than a feeling...it falls over itself to outperform and out woke every other white ‚Äúally.‚Äù

Penitential whiteness might look and sound desirable, but I can guarantee you that it absolutely is not. It is exhausting.

Penitential whiteness is a paradox.

It demands labor by performing labor. Instead of lending quiet support behind the scenes, it is loud and in front. It needs the cookies and badges from Black people. If no cookies are given, there is an assumption that something went wrong, and so the penitential white person become insecure and needs to make sure they‚Äôre still a ‚Äúgood person.‚Äù

It centers itself by de-centering whiteness. Penitential whiteness makes sure that everyone knows that they are not in the center by telling everyone that they aren‚Äôt in the center. They are in the center of all of the fe-centering.

Penitential whiteness does everything at full steam. If it‚Äôs calling out other white folks penitent white folks will be the loudest and most persistent. If it is if it‚Äôs raising awareness, you can expect a full, scripted pitch. If it is showing up, it will be the first one there and the last to leave.

Penitential whiteness, on the surface, might seem like a healthy expression of allyship (or whatever y‚Äôall calling it right now). The difference between being a healthy co-conspirator and a penitential white individual is about posture. Penitential white folks can do good work, but that good work is rooted in relieving the pressure to prove their goodness rather than in the liberation of others.

Beware and be wary of penitential whiteness. It‚Äôs not a good look. At the end of the day, penitential whiteness does more harm than good because the ‚Äúwork‚Äù of a penitential person of whiteness is rooted in their zeal to prove themselves.

Penitential whiteness does not combat white supremacy, it reinforces it by‚Äîonce again‚Äîmaking people of whiteness the hero of their own narratives. The narrative, in this case, is being The Best Ally That Ever Allied and sucking all of the air (and liberation) out of the room.

I don‚Äôt expect everyone to understand or agree with this word. But I hope that it will at least get folks thinking about how they approach the work of antiracism.

See More
item.author: SURJ Denver

Party for Socialism and Liberation - Denver

The Democratic National Convention proves exactly how far right the Democrat Party continues to move. It was also an exercise in cowardly fear in the face of Trump‚Äôs open redbaiting and Muslim baiting. That was the stated reason that the party‚Äôs most popular liberal member of the House, Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez, received just 90 seconds to speak. That‚Äôs precisely why the Biden team joined in Trump‚Äôs condemnation of Palestinian activist Linda Sarsour after she spoke as an invited guest on a panel discussion at the convention. That‚Äôs why Republican billionaires, militarists and anti-abortion politicians were given major roles.

item.title: On August 5th, 2020, Djibril Diol, Adja Diol, Khadija Diol,...
item.content:encoded:
Black Lives Matter 5280

On August 5th, 2020, Djibril Diol, Adja Diol, Khadija Diol, Hassan Diol (Djibril's sister), and Hawa Baye (Hassan's infant daughter) were victims of an intentional arson of their home. Their Denver home was set on fire by an unknown perpetrator at 2:30 A.M. 3 adults inside were able to escape with no life-threatening injuries, but the 5 aforementioned individuals were killed.
The Denver police department is offering a $14,000 reward for information leading to the arrest of th...e killer, and the department is actively investigating the case as an arson. The Denver police have said they will not move forward with labeling this as a hate crime as they "do not want to narrow the scope of the investigation."
This petition has been created to raise awareness of what has happened to the Diol family, as the media coverage has been severely lacking. We are demanding the Denver police department increase their focus on this case and that they do not let up until their killer has been arrested, charged, and convicted. The continued trend of police departments undervaluing the lives of BIPOC individuals and failing to hold their murderers accountable must end now. Share this petition as much as possible to ensure the Diol family gets the justice they so desperately deserve.

GOFUNDME LINK IN COMMENTS to support the family with funeral expenses and basic necessities.

https://www.change.org/p/jared-polis-justice-for-the-diol-f‚Ä¶

See MoreJustice for the Diol Family

change.org

Sign the Petition

item.title: Please support & share! A Statement From The Fundraisers:...
item.content:encoded:
Denver Action Network

Please support & share!

A Statement From The Fundraisers:
"This bail fund is for #Denver demonstrators who were arrested on Saturday August 22, 2020 for confronting the Denver Police Department for what it is: a violently racist and authoritarian institution.

...

After years of police murder and the terrorizing our unhoused neighbors, we are FED UP! Last Wednesday, when 40+ DPD officers brutalized community members assisting unhoused neighbors with sweeps, we drew a line in the sand. Enough is enough!

We demand justice for our unhoused neighbors, as well as the families of William Debose, Alexis Mendez-Perez, Paul Castaway, Michael Marshall, Marvin Booker, Ryan Ronquillo, Jessie Hernandez and the thousands of people in our city impacted by state-backed violence. The Denver City Council has failed to hear our calls for justice, liberation and abolition. We know that human rights only come alive when citizens organize, protest, boycott, rebel and violate the law in order to uphold justice!

Twelve comrades were arrested last night. Some were released on PR bond but we still have 3 bonds of $500 each to pay and two comrades with bond not allowed until court on Monday afternoon. Please help raise the ransom for these brave rebels and get them out of cages with an active COVID outbreak! Let's get our comrades back to their loved ones, their pets and their jobs tonight!

As the election approaches, we are looking to make an active bail fund for rebels. Any excess monies will be put into this revolving fund as we work to create it! We will update this post when fundraising goals gave been met!

Solidarity & Power"
‚úäüè¥üö©üî•

Enough is enough and we demand justice for our ...unhoused neighbors, the families of our black and brown neighbors murdered by DPD and the thousands of people in our city impacted by state-backed violence. item.title: #FreeThemAll ‚Äú10 of the top 10 infection clusters in the...
item.content:encoded:
Abolish ICE Denver

#FreeThemAll
‚Äú10 of the top 10 infection clusters in the United States are linked to correctional facilities. Of the top 100 clusters, 87 are tied to detention centers. It is morbidly unsurprising that the virus is ravaging jails and prisons, where cramped quarters make social distancing impossible. Prisons are increasingly relying on lockdowns to restrict movement, leading to a staggering jump in the number of people in isolation or solitary confinement. Half of all states are not requiring correctional staff to wear masks. Matters are made worse by insufficient sanitation materials, and, all too often, a culture of cruelty and disregard for the well-being of incarcerated people.‚Äù

As cases soar among inmates, decarceration efforts are lagging.

washingtonpost.com

Opinion | Coronavirus cases in prisons are exploding. More people need to be let out.

As cases soar among inmates, decarceration efforts are lagging.As cases soar among inmates, decarceration efforts are lagging.

‚ÄúEl necesita ayuda, est√° solo, he tocado puertas en Chelsea pero nadie me ayuda, a don Miguel lo votaron sin raz√≥n alguna‚Äù

item.title: V√≠a La Resistencia We've confirmed that Victor is back at...
item.content:encoded:
Abolish ICE Denver

V√≠a La Resistencia We've confirmed that Victor is back at NWDC‚Äîfor now. You all mobilized quickly this morning to show up with banners and signs at the airport, to contact the director of ICE‚Äôs Seattle field office, to share our livestreams and calls to action. That pressure halted Victor's deportation for now!

But the fight isn't over. We‚Äôre told that Victor will likely face deportation next week. We want him reunited with his wife and children in Pasco. We want him free. An...d we want NWDC shut down once and for all.

We've known all along that ICE lies, but today we saw once again that nothing they say can be trusted. We saw once again that ICE won't hesitate to send people to their deaths. The Mexican consulate must not be complicit in this violence.
üö®üö®üö®üö®üö®üö®üö®üö®
We need to flood the phone lines at consulate offices in both Seattle and San Diego to urge staff not to collaborate with ICE on Victor's deportation.

Seattle:
Farid Alejandro Soberanis Garcia
(206) 448-3526‚Äã dial 5 then ext.101
fsoberanis@sre.gob.mx
Twitter: @ConsulmexSEA
Facebook: @ConsulMexSEA

San Diego:
Victor Esponda
(619) 231-8414
Twitter: @consulmexsdi
Facebook: @Consulmexsd
vesponda@sre.gob.mx
If email bounces, tag @Consulmexsd and tweet @carlos_glezgtez

Sample Script:
‚Äú'I‚Äôm calling/e-mailing you as a ‚Äã(fill in... WA resident, WA teacher, parent, community member, etc.)‚Äã to ask that you‚Äã refuse to collaborate with ICE on the deportation of ViÃÅctor JimeÃÅnez GutieÃÅrrez.‚Äã Mr. JimeÃÅnez GutieÃÅrrez is a 62 year-old blind man, having lost his sight due to diabetic complications. ICE terrorizes our communities and knowingly sends people to their deaths by deporting people like Mr JimeÃÅnez with serious illnesses and disabilities. The consulate must not collaborate with ICE in carrying out this violent agenda. Deportations and detention during this global pandemic put all of us at risk. The time to act on ending immigration detention is now, and the consulate has a central role to play.‚Äù

item.title: "The only jail in Oregon that holds federal immigration...
item.content:encoded:
Abolish ICE Denver

"The only jail in Oregon that holds federal immigration detainees has said it will end the practice.

The board that oversees the Northern Oregon Regional Correctional Facility in The Dalles unanimously agreed on Thursday to initiate steps toward ending its contract with U.S. Immigration Customs and Enforcement. The board declined an interview to explain what brought about the decision or the fiscal impact. But said in a statement the overall number detainees has dropped resulting in less revenue for the jail."

The board that oversees the Northern Oregon Regional Correctional Facility in The Dalles unanimously agreed on Thursday to initiate steps to end its contract with Immigration Customs and Enforcement.

item.title: This Black August, there can be no doubt that the conditions...
item.content:encoded:
Party for Socialism and Liberation - Denver

This Black August, there can be no doubt that the conditions that George Jackson and the prisoners of the Attica Rebellion lost their lives rebelling against in 1971 are still in place today. The neglect this government shows to Black, Brown, Indigenous, LGBTQ+ and poor folks on a daily basis is doubled behind prison walls, and tripled under pandemic conditions.

Today we brought our protest to the Denver County Jail, the Denver Women‚Äôs Correctional Facility, and the Aurora G...EO ICE Detention Center. Though this system tries to hide the horrendous abuse that happens behind bars out of sight, we will not leave behind those in cages in our struggle. We raise the following demands, recognizing that if they are not met, more unnecessary death is a certainty:

1. Immediate humanitarian release of all ICE detainees and all vulnerable inmates, those convicted for non-violent offenses, and those who have not been convicted at all.

2. Where people remain behind bars, drastically increase medical staffing and supplies to local jails and state prisons, and guarantee sanitary conditions for all inmates.

3. Free all political prisoners!

Thank you to Black Lives Matter 5280, Sanctuary4All Colorado for cohosting this event! #FreeThemAll #LiberaATodos

See More+9

item.title: ‚ÄúOn Friday, the Denver Alliance for Street Health Response...
item.content:encoded:
Representative Leslie Herod

‚ÄúOn Friday, the Denver Alliance for Street Health Response announced it‚Äôs been working with Aurora City Council members since January to discuss how they could bring such a program to the city. It‚Äôs modeled after the Crisis Assistance Helping Out on the Streets program in Eugene, Oregon. The goal of CAHOOT is to provide ‚Äúa more appropriate and more humane‚Äù approach to crisis intervention for people experiencing homelessness and mental health and substance use disorders.‚Äù

Denverite

The city is exploring a pilot program similar to Support Team Assisted Response, or STAR, in Denver.

item.title: Thank you for joining this call Director Baldermann!
item.content:encoded:
Denver School Board Director - Tay Anderson

Thank you for joining this call Director Baldermann!

Scott Baldermann, Denver Public Schools Board of Education - District 1

Every day the Denver school principals and assistant principals work to ensure that students have the best possible learning environment, and that their staffs ...experience a positive school climate. Research shows that next to teachers, principals are the second most important factor in influencing student achievement.

Their leadership is essential to helping families in their community feel welcome and included as partners in their child‚Äôs education. School Leaders are critical for the success of each child, and they must have a contract to afford children the leadership they deserve.

As a group, they need to be included with district senior leadership on all major policy decisions that affect their daily lives. They should also be compensated fairly for their contributions to the welfare of all students.

For these reasons and more, I support the recognition of the Denver School Leaders Association as a collective bargaining unit in Denver Public Schools. I will work with district leadership and my Board colleagues to ensure approval.

See MoreTheir goals include fighting for fair compensation and against institutional racism.

item.title: Denver Alliance for Street Health Response is doing the work....
item.content:encoded:
Showing Up for Racial Justice - SURJ Denver

Denver Alliance for Street Health Response is doing the work. Check out the planned efforts in Aurora for alternatives to police.

[ID: Purple square with white text on top of black background that says ‚ÄúBreaking: Aurora to explore non police response.‚Äù DASHR logo on bottom right corner]

Denver Alliance for Street Health Response

BREAKING: Today we make public our work to help create a non-police alternative in Aurora similar to CAHOOTS. We were part of launching a pilot in Denver earlie...r this year called STAR and we hope to have a program in Aurora very soon. Please see the full press release below or on our website: http://dashrco.org/‚Ä¶/press-release-city-of-aurora-to-pur‚Ä¶/2/

FOR IMMEDIATE RELEASE

August 21, 2020

Contacts:

Vinnie Cervantes, DASHR
720.413.0124 | vinnie@dashrco.org

Natalia Marshall, Aurora resident and activist
nmarshall02@gmail.com

Councilwoman Allison Hiltz, Aurora City Council
303.739.7015 | ahiltz@auroragov.org

CITY OF AURORA TO PURSUE NON-POLICE MODEL FOR EMERGENCY CALLS

Aurora joins Denver as cities in Colorado looking to explore alternatives similar to Eugene model.

Denver, CO - The organization Denver Alliance for Street Health Response (DASHR) was founded in 2018 with the hopes of creating a non-police emergency response in Denver, CO inspired by a program in Oregon called CAHOOTS (Crisis Assistance Helping Out On The Streets). The program provides a more appropriate and more humane approach to crisis involving homelessness, mental health, and substance use. The CAHOOTS program answers about one-fifth of the 911 calls in Eugene and saves the city on average $8 million per year. DASHR‚Äôs efforts, alongside other community groups and partners, resulted in the launch of the new STAR (Support Team Assisted Response) pilot program in Denver on June 1st.

Since January, DASHR has also been working with members of Aurora‚Äôs City Council to explore building a model similar to CAHOOTS. ‚ÄúAurora currently has a co-responder model, but we know that a police presence can escalate a situation,‚Äú said Councilwoman Allison Hiltz who chairs the public safety committee on council. ‚ÄúIn looking at other models, we are better able to prioritize our community‚Äôs needs and rethink how we deliver mental health care.‚Äù She plans to present a brief update on their progress at a committee meeting on August 27, with hopes for a more complete proposal in the near future.

Natalia Marshall, whose uncle Michael Marshall was killed in the Denver jail noted that this type of response could prevent similar things from happening. ‚ÄúMy uncle Michael had schizophrenia and when he called police to report his bible as stolen, he was met by police officers instead of mental health professionals who brought him to the jail, which led to his death.‚Äù She adds that he needed mental health services not jail. Natalia is an Aurora resident and activist for alternatives to police and criminal justice reform.

DASHR strongly believes in creating alternatives to policing, jail, and the prison industrial complex more generally. ‚ÄúI believe we‚Äôre in a critical moment where the ideas we‚Äôve been fighting to achieve for years are finally getting the attention and consideration they‚Äôve always deserved,‚Äù said Vinnie Cervantes, Organizing Director of DASHR. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs important that our solutions are truly alternatives to systemic harm and that they are led by the community‚Äù DASHR is committed to helping facilitate community involvement in the programs.

About DASHR
Denver Alliance for Street Health Response (DASHR) is a coalition of groups and individuals who create and support community- based responses to crisis and conflict, as well as forge new narratives of public health and safety.

See More

item.title: ‚ÄúThe tool is used in about two dozen Colorado counties,...
item.content:encoded:
Representative Leslie Herod

‚ÄúThe tool is used in about two dozen Colorado counties, including Denver. And its apparent racial bias means Black people may be more likely to have to pay higher cash bail amounts, which judges use as an unspoken means to detain people they deem a threat to public safety. And for those who are released, the higher scores mean Black people may end up facing more strict pretrial supervision requirements, including regular check-ins, surveillance, curfews, and sobriety and drug tests. Failure to comply with such bond conditions can result in new charges and even jail time. ‚Äú

Colorado Newsline

A new study found that the most widely used bond risk assessment tool in Colorado courts scored Black people as riskier than white people.

Qui√©n te dijo que emigrar a otro pa√≠s te dar√≠a la gran vida? Pu√©s te cuento que te minti√≥ ...emigrar es trabajar de lo que salga ( que sea Honesto y Honrado) es aguantar insultos, ofensas,gritos, es levantarte muy de madrugada y acostarte muy de noche,a veces hasta dormir en la calle es callar y llorar en silencio, es dejar de comprarte algo para ahorrar, es luchar cada d√≠a...no tienes idea lo que cuesta ganarce 100 d√≥lares o euros...dormirte con... dolor en los pies en la espalda...querer abrazar a alguien al terminar la jornada y solo tienes a tu almohada, es querer tener alas para volar e irte
Es eso y m√°s ...asi que si un familiar te env√≠a auque sea 10 d√≥lares ora por ella o el ...ya que no tienes ideas de lo que le cost√≥ gan√°rselo...as√≠ que solo te pido algo ora mucho por los emigrantes, no te burles de ellosüò™ Solo Dios es testigo de lo que se sufreüò¢

item.title: Today I requested a point of personal privilege to say the...
item.content:encoded:
Denver School Board Director - Tay Anderson

Today I requested a point of personal privilege to say the following:

Thank you President Olson,

I wanted to take a moment to address my fellow School Board Directors, the DPS community, and our city.

...

Over the course of the summer we have seen our communities rise up in the face of injustice. From George Floyd, to Breonna Taylor, and even here at home for Elijah McClain.

Our duties as School Board Directors do not stop when we turn our zoom meetings off or when the President uses her gavel to adjourn our meetings.

Over the summer I witnessed the inexcusable treatment of those that are unhoused, I witnessed our DPS staff and children gassed and shot at during demonstrations for Black lives, and we must never forget that those issues are intersectional with our duties as elected leaders of the largest school district in the state of Colorado. We have thousands of families in our district that face homelessness every year, our Black students and staff are ALWAYS faced with the reality that at any moment they could become another hashtag.

I have not neglected my role as one of the seven Directors, I have transformed it to represent the voice of the unheard.

Taking bold and unapologetic stances has led to our board receiving emails in support of my actions and emails that are not in support of my actions. My former campaign staff, family, and myself have been subject to harassment and death threats from those that oppose the way I stand up for community.

The calls for my resignation have been from a very small portion of folks, but allow me to give a direct response. I will not be resigning from the Denver School Board.
I am grateful to my colleagues, community, and family for their ongoing support.

I have taken time to reflect on my actions and how I show up in our community, which is why over the coming months I will work with my colleagues to outline a process for the DPS Board to more clearly define how we show up when acting on behalf of the Board of Education and Denver Public Schools and individually, so there is no longer any confusion between our personal views and actions and our elected responsibilities.

As I said before I entered this office, my activism doesn‚Äôt turn off because I assumed a title, it turns up. For those that may have missed the memo, I am unapologetically Director Tay Anderson, but before anything else I am a Black man in America.

My mission has always been the same since day one and that is building a better Denver Public Schools FOR THE STUDENTS.

Thank you and I yield the remainder of my time.

See More

item.title: On 8/26, join families of vulnerable incarcerated Coloradans for...
item.content:encoded:
ACLU of Colorado

On 8/26, join families of vulnerable incarcerated Coloradans for a virtual panel on the need to release at-risk people from prison. Learn from our six inspiring panelists and take action to bring our at-risk neighbors safely home! RSVP at http://bit.ly/3iPuRMB or in the event below.

Our panelists include:
Amber Johnson, whose 62-year-old father, Ronald, has turned his life around in prison after being convicted of non-violent offenses related to substance abuse.

...

Will Cranfill, whose incarcerated father, James, is a 62-year-old grandfather, artist and Navy veteran who suffers from chronic inflammatory lung disease, a condition that puts him at grave risk of serious illness and death from COVID-19.

Sandra Winston, whose husband, Gary, is a 58-year-old grandfather with severe respiratory problems serving a one-year sentence for drug possession at Sterling, the site of Colorado‚Äôs largest COVID-19 outbreak.

Hassan Latif is the Executive Director and Founder of the Second Chance Center, where he works with justice involved men and women to lead lives of success and fulfillment. The Second Chance Center offers case management, mentoring, and vital resources to assist formerly incarcerated individuals in reestablishing their lives and becoming successful members of the community.

Erica Grossman is a partner in the law firm of Holland, Holland Edwards & Grossman. Erica has litigated a number of cases involving police brutality, unconstitutional jail conditions, first amendment issues, discrimination, and retaliation. She is the ACLU-CO‚Äôs cooperating counsel in the lawsuit against the Colorado Department of Corrections and the Governor for their failure to protect our vulnerable, incarcerated neighbors from COVID-19.

Gail Johnson has more than two decades of experience representing clients in criminal and civil cases in federal and state courts in Colorado, California, and the District of Columbia. You can read about several of Gail‚Äôs clients incarcerated in CDOC with serious underlying medical conditions, including Demika Rogers, Chris Nye and Gary Winston, at https://aclu-co.org/no-one-deserves-to-die-from-covid-19/

Our communities deserve better. PSL has been talking to our neighbors about the police and we have heard too many mothers tell us they keep their children inside because of the police, or they religiously call their adult children every Sunday to make sure they survived the cops‚Äô weekend patrols.

We need to fight back! Join the Denver-Aurora March Against Racism & Police Violence (https://www.facebook.com/events/351526215840428/) on August 30 and encourage your neighbors and friends to come with you. Only the people united can put an end to racist police terror!

item.title: ‚ÄúSuch shootings are "so routine that even during a...
item.content:encoded:
Colorado Attorneys Against Police Violence

‚ÄúSuch shootings are "so routine that even during a national pandemic, with far fewer people traveling outside of their homes and police departments reducing contact with the public so as not to spread the virus, police have continued to fatally shoot people at the same rate so far in 2020 as they did in the same period from 2015 to 2019," according to the report, which was based on data analysis from the University of Nebraska at Omaha.‚Äù

#DefundPolice #DismantlePolice #HoldCopsAccountable #CAAPV

item.title: Even during a pandemic, with fewer people traveling outside...
item.content:encoded:
ACLU of Colorado

Even during a pandemic, with fewer people traveling outside their homes, fatal shootings by police in Colorado have become an epidemic. We are one of 7 states in the nation where fatal police shootings are higher than the past five years on average.

In 2020, police have killed 27 people in Colorado. From 2014‚Äì2019 police killed 189 people in Colorado ‚Äî the 5th highest rate for fatal police shootings in the nation.

Of the 100 largest cities in America, Aurora is ranked 8th in ...the country for police killings. Denver is ranked 16th. It's time to transform policing in Colorado by dramatically reducing police departments‚Äô responsibilities, power and funding.

READ THE REPORT: https://www.aclu.org/‚Ä¶/other-epidemic-fatal-police-shooting‚Ä¶

item.title: Last July, President Trump and administration officials announced to the public that Immigration and Customs Enforcement...
item.content:encoded:
Last July, President Trump and administration officials announced to the public that Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) was planning an operation to target thousands of immigrant families that have received final deportation orders- a carefully coordinated push that was to target on up to 10 "sanctuary" cities across the country.

Many of us in the Coalition to Close the Concentation Camps knew that it was time to take action against forces of fascism and evil- especially for our families impacted by this broken immigration system. On July 12, 2019, radicals and impacted families split from the milquetoast Lights for Liberty vigil being conducted at the Aurora ICE Processing Center. Rebels marched into the parking lot of GEO- where anticolonial speeches were given by indigenous youth and where the now infamous flag removal occurred.

Following the flag removal and international embarrassment, the Aurora Police Department began a Twitter manhunt offering a $4k reward to identify suspects from that evening; violent crimes typically only get a $1k reward and we knew this outrageously large reward was made because two anti police flags were flown that night. Cowards at APD wouldn't fire or prosecute the murderers of Elijah McClain the following month, yet APD had the time and resources to target non-violent protestors demanding justice for immigrants.

The woman featured in this powerful photo, Michelle, was eventually identified by non profit "allies" and served misdemeanor tampering charges; Michelle's case with Aurora dragged on for over a year. Today we have some good news: our hero was found NOT GUILTY by jury trial and walks free of all charges! Fuck APD!

Michelle- you are an inspiration and a true Chingona. With you, our city sent a message to the Department of Homeland Security. Your bravery, in addition to the life Willem Van Spronsen gave on July 13th 2019 by setting ICE's kidnapping vans in Tacoma ablaze, made ICE retreat on their planned nationwide mass arrests of immigrants.

#ChingaLaMigra #AbolishICE
Photo by @buffalo_heart_images
item.author: Abolish ICE Denver

item.title: Demika Rogers has spent 15 years incarcerated. During that time,...
item.content:encoded:
ACLU of Colorado

Demika Rogers has spent 15 years incarcerated. During that time, she has dramatically transformed herself into a leader who works to help others. She is a chef, actor, facilitator for the Alternatives to Violence Program, founder of the Women of Influence program and active participant in the New Beginnings Church. She has also raised hundreds of dollars for nonprofits. She dreams of returning to her three children and one day starting a nonprofit of her own to help children whose parents are incarcerated. Redemption is real.

Inmates at the Denver Women's Correctional Facility perform A Christmas Carol.

9news.com

A story of redemption that transcends the stage

Inmates at the Denver Women's Correctional Facility perform A Christmas Carol.Inmates at the Denver Women's Correctional Facility perform A Christmas Carol.

item.title: From @denverpsl: On August 21, 1971, the murder of revolutionary George Jackson at San Quentin State Prison ignited what...
item.content:encoded:
From @denverpsl: On August 21, 1971, the murder of revolutionary George Jackson at San Quentin State Prison ignited what we celebrate today as #BlackAugust. Black August, first commemorated by our incarcerated brothers and sisters, is a time to recommit ourselves to the struggle for #BlackLiberation and to honor those who’ve contributed to our collective progress and all those who have been lost to unjust violence and systemic racism.
This August 21, join us in a car protest to bring the Black August fight to our local prison walls. We will drive in a mobile protest to the Denver County Jail and the GEO Aurora ICE detention facility to let those who are chained there know that we are with them, we are fighting for them, and we will keep fighting until all chains are broken.
The many injustices faced by those behind bars in the U.S. are today amplified by the COVID-19 pandemic. Prisons and jails all across the country, where medical neglect is commonplace and quarantining impossible, have become hotspots of infection. Hundreds have died in US prisons from COVID-19, and yet no response has been made to defend against unnecessary death. The mass incarceration of Black, Brown, and Indigenous populations means that they are not only disproportionately affected by the virus outside of jail, but inside as well.
We raise the following demands, recognizing that if they are not met, more unnecessary death is a certainty:
1. Immediate humanitarian release of all ICE detainees and all vulnerable inmates, those convicted for non-violent offenses, and those who have not been convicted at all.
2. Where people remain behind bars, drastically increase medical staffing and supplies to local jails and state prisons, and guarantee sanitary conditions for all inmates.
3. Free all political prisoners!
#FreeThemAll #DecarcerateNOW #decarcerateCOVID19
item.author: Black Lives Matter 5280

We‚Äôll keep fighting for everyone‚Äôs right to the ballot.

item.title: Pictured here are Kesha, her husband Pablo, and their daughter...
item.content:encoded:
Sanctuary4All Colorado is in Denver, Colorado.

Pictured here are Kesha, her husband Pablo, and their daughter Leah. You might recognize Kesha and Leah from their incredible work at the @abolishicedenver encampment that took place in front of the GEO detention center in Aurora this summer. Kesha and Leah spent 79 days camped there advocating for Pablo‚Äôs freedom and the freedom of all people detained inside. Kesha‚Äôs work‚Äîleading nightly vigils, talking with media, selling t-shirts, helped raise thousands of dollars not just... for her husband‚Äôs legal costs but also those of other impacted families. Her advocacy also led to the universal COVID testing provided at the facility (at that time, one of only two in the country to test everyone inside). On July 11 her husband was transferred to Teller county in retaliation for their activism, but Kesha stayed at GEO advocating for the liberation of all detainees. Support her this weekend by buying tacos. tinyurl.com/solidaritymealsaugust22 @ Denver, Colorado

item.title: ‚ÄúA July study by the University of Northern Colorado found...
item.content:encoded:
Colorado Attorneys Against Police Violence

‚ÄúA July study by the University of Northern Colorado found that the most widely used risk assessment tool in Colorado, known as the Colorado Pretrial Assessment Tool, or CPAT, scored Black people higher than white people even though their odds of missing a court date or committing a new offense were nearly the same. It also inaccurately scored people experiencing homelessness higher than other people, the study shows.

The CPAT‚Äôs potential bias may be rooted in the following ...‚Äúrisk factors‚Äù considered in the 12-question survey: ‚Äúhaving a home or cell phone,‚Äù ‚Äúowning or renting one‚Äôs residence‚Äù and ‚Äúage at first arrest.‚Äù Reformers have said for years these items are less a measure of risk and more a measure of poverty and policing behavior.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs like we‚Äôre gonna put a veneer on it and call it>#EndCashBail #CAAPV

https://coloradonewsline.com/‚Ä¶/bias-against-black-people-f‚Ä¶/

See MoreA new study found that the most widely used bond risk assessment tool in Colorado courts scored Black people as riskier than white people.

coloradonewsline.com

Bias against Black people found in Colorado bail reform tool - Colorado Newsline

A new study found that the most widely used bond risk assessment tool in Colorado courts scored Black people as riskier than white people.A new study found that the most widely used bond risk assessment tool in Colorado courts scored Black people as riskier than white people.
item.author: Colorado Attorneys Against Police Violence

item.title: Dru Nielsen and I just tried a 1st Degree Murder case in Denver....
item.content:encoded:
Colorado Attorneys Against Police Violence

Dru Nielsen and I just tried a 1st Degree Murder case in Denver. It was challenging both because of Covid-19 and our client‚Äôs innocence (which he walked in and away with). I‚Äôm here to say that in 2021 I will work on legislation in Colorado that will strip these ‚Äúoh so powerful‚Äù prosecutors of their full immunity, force them to pay defense costs upon acquittal, and institute a law that requires DA‚Äôs offices to disclose when their deputies have been found to commit misconduct, or hidden or destroyed discovery. If any of these these three laws were enacted, our client - and many others - would never be charged with baseless and speculative crimes.
item.author: Colorado Attorneys Against Police Violence

item.title: North Denver for Social JusticeDenver Homeless Out LoudSweep Planned for Monday at 12th and Acoma Where People Moved After Lincoln Park...
item.content:encoded:
North Denver for Social JusticeDenver Homeless Out Loud

Sweep Planned for Monday at 12th and Acoma Where People Moved After Lincoln Park Sweep

Homeless Whack-a-Mole Is Not An Answer

#SOLUTIONSNOTSWEEPS

...

On Monday morning, August 17th 2020, the City plans to sweep the newly formed camp at 12th and Acoma where residents of the Lincoln Park camp moved after that sweep. When will the City ever learn that homeless whack-a-mole does not work!?? It does not create housing, it does not connect people to the little housing that there is, it does not solve health and safety concerns, it does not make homelessness disappear. We need Solutions Not Sweeps!!*&!

In the early days of COVID the city publicly agreed to ‚Äúnot displace people or their property‚Äù from encampments. Then they back tracked on that‚Ä¶They lied to the community. But there was a standing agreement from the City under the Department of Transportation and Infrastructure (DOTI) that, ‚ÄúDue to the COVID-19 crisis, once the area is cleaned, people experiencing homelessness may return to the cleaned area, if they choose to do so.‚Äù We are demanding they at least follow this agreement!

Even better the City should actually start following the CDC guidance - not sweeping encampments and rather providing necessary sanitation resources.

Displacing everyone even for a day instead of providing sanitation resources, support resources, and ultimately housing is not the answer...But scattering everyone to who knows where is fundamentally not a solution.

We cannot keep pretending homelessness will disappear with sweeps. If we even want homelessness to disappear we have to start fighting for attainable housing for ALL and not fighting the visibility of homelessness.

Be there Monday morning at 12th and Acoma. Demand Solutions Not Sweeps!!!

Note: There is also a planned sweep at 13th and Washington on Tuesday August 18th, as well as a likely swept attempt at 29th and Welton that day.

Contact:
info@denverhomelessoutloud.org
720-940-5291

See More
item.author: North Denver for Social Justice

item.title: "All we are asking is to be transferred back to the Aurora facility. We are not asking for a release. They have the...
item.content:encoded:
"All we are asking is to be transferred back to the Aurora facility. We are not asking for a release. They have the authority to transfer us immediately if we want," says Jimmy Sodhi, a 45-year-old ICE detainee.

Sodhi is part of a group of eight ICE detainees who have been housed in the same dormitory at the Teller County Jail since being transferred there from the Aurora Contract Detention Facility one month ago. Sodhi and the other ICE detainees began the hunger strike on the morning of August 10 to protest what they allege are significantly worse conditions at Aurora GEO.

"As a Sikh, I'm not allowed to wear my Sikh bracelet, I'm not allowed to cover my head. If I have to pray, it's required for me to cover my head. I'm told to cover my head with a pillowcase or a towel," says Sodhi, who has been in ICE custody since March 2017 and is currently in the appeals process of his deportation case stemming from a fraud conviction for insider trading. "That is very demeaning, very disrespectful."

Sodhi notes that he was allowed to wear his turban at the Aurora detention facility, but has been told by staff at the Teller County Jail that he cannot retrieve his turban from his personal belongings. Same with prayer books, Sodhi adds, which he hasn't been able to obtain, being told by staff that "there's no chaplain here and we don't have those here."

Additionally, Sodhi contends that he and other ICE detainees at the Teller County Jail have been subjected to racial harassment perpetrated by non-ICE detainees staying in the same dormitory.

[...]

Adding to his angst, Sodhi contends that he and the other detainees don't even know why they're being housed in the Teller County Jail, which has an agreement with ICE to house immigrant detainees.

Via @denverwestword @conormichael28
item.author: Abolish ICE Denver

item.title: ‚ÄúA key element of the pragmatic argument is to play up the...
item.content:encoded:
Party for Socialism and Liberation - Denver

‚ÄúA key element of the pragmatic argument is to play up the ‚Äúhistoric‚Äù importance of the current election. Even if we oppose the Democrats on a good many issues, this year the Republicans are so evil and the implications so grave that we must ‚Äútactically‚Äù and ‚Äútemporarily‚Äù unite with the Democratic Party. But the notion of ‚Äútemporary‚Äù support is disproven by the fact these ‚Äúleftists‚Äù have been saying the exact same thing every four years for decades!

What they are reinforcing ...is not some tactical exception, but a political strategy based on repeated and periodic unity with the ‚Äúless evil‚Äù section of the ruling class.

What has this strategy, the same at each election, delivered? Even when the Democrats have been in complete control of government, the year-to-year drift in U.S. politics has been towards the right, attacks on labor, severe austerity, a racist and draconian criminal justice system and renewed assaults on women‚Äôs rights. This has been the case under Obama too.
...
Two points must be emphasized: 1) To shift the political climate in favor of poor and working people requires a mass movement embodying their demands. 2) The Democratic Party will never represent such a movement, and only seek to misrepresent it for its own purposes.

Millions of people agree with the first point, but are not yet sure of the second. The elections must be used as a venue to speak directly to these issues, clarify the nature of capitalism and expose the country‚Äôs political leadership.‚Äù

See MoreWhile defenders of the "lesser evil" Democratic Party believe they are holding the line against even further right-wing encroachment, they in fact encourage it. #elections #socialism

liberationnews.org

‚ÄòLesser-evil‚Äô politics demoralize and demobilize progressives

While defenders of the "lesser evil" Democratic Party believe they are holding the line against even further right-wing encroachment, they in fact encourage it. #elections #socialismWhile defenders of the "lesser evil" Democratic Party believe they are holding the line against even further right-wing encroachment, they in fact encourage it. #elections #socialism

ACLU of Colorado

Since being transferred to Teller, the men report being unable to practice their religion, forced to live in unsanitary conditions with dirty clothes and subjected to racial harassment and threats of violence. Imagine how bad it must be if they'd rather go back to GEO.

They want to return to the Aurora facility.

westword.com

ICE Detainees in Teller County Jail Start Hunger Strike Over Conditions

They want to return to the Aurora facility.They want to return to the Aurora facility.

item.title: Join the exciting livestream party on Monday August 10th at 4pm...
item.content:encoded:
Party for Socialism and Liberation - Denver

Join the exciting livestream party on Monday August 10th at 4pm Pacific / 7pm Eastern to send letters to Mutulu Shakur.

Mutulu Shakur contributed to civil rights black and liberation struggles in the late 1960‚Äôs to the 1980‚Äôs. He also participated in presentations to the United Nations about the racism experienced by Black people in the U.S. He has been imprisoned for 33 years and denied parole eight times, during this time he was diagnosed with bone cancer. He needs our support!

Party for Socialism and Liberation - PSL was live.

item.title: An update from Abolish ICE Denver & Camp #FreeThemAll The...
item.content:encoded:
Denver Action Network

An update from Abolish ICE Denver & Camp #FreeThemAll

The number of filled beds have drastically been reduced at the GEO concentration camp in #Aurora & many have been freed due to the camps' work.

Well done, friends ‚úä

Abolish ICE Denver

Rest is radical and Camp #FreeThemAll has voted to lift up camp to allow our beloved community to rest and renew. We are still in this fight for the long haul -... aka until we #FreeThemAll.

Camp Free Them All has been a success in that we: saved lives, forced Aurora GEO to be one of two detention centers in the so-called United States to be offering COVID testing, forced a congressional hearing on COVID in ICE detention centers, stopped an illegal deportation, supported families with love & money and we built so much power together this summer! ‚úäüíñ

Despite these successes, we found out last week that nearly a third of the detainees are now being quarantined due to COVID and we fully intend to keep up the pressure on GEO, ICE & DHS.

Stay tuned for our next steps at Aurora GEO and if you want to help keep impacted families out of ICE custody, please donate directly to families!

Venmo: Sanctuary-4-All
Cashapp: $abolishicedenver

Tomorrow we ask that you please come get your belongings or contact us about storage. Any items not picked up will be given to unhoused neighbors and other struggles for liberation.

And please join us for a special Sunday vigil and Pablo's birthday celebration!

https://facebook.com/events/s/pablos-birthday-vigil/749228552534363/?ti=cl

See More

item.title: Tomorrow Morning, 8/5 #EndTheSweeps #DoBetterDenver
item.content:encoded:
Denver Action Network

Tomorrow Morning, 8/5

#EndTheSweeps
#DoBetterDenver

Denver Homeless Out Loud

Likely Sweep Tomorrow (Wednesday) at 13th and Clarkson Encampment

Be There. No More Move Along to NoWhere Orders‚Ä¶

Wednesday August 5th 2020, 7am to ??

...

So far today, the City has not come in to sweep the encampment around Morey school as we expect to happen either today or tomorrow. This means they will very likely come tomorrow (Wednesday 8/5) to try and sweep everyone out. We cannot stand for this continued whack-a-mole ‚Äúsolution‚Äù to homelessness. As is stated in the CDC guidance, if you cannot offer individual housing options for everyone, you should not sweep people along...with nowhere to go.

Make your demand heard tomorrow morning by showing up to 13th and Clarkson at 7am to stand up for housing, not sweeps.

School is not starting in person until October at the earliest. We should be using these months to get folks housing or at least another stable place encampments with necessary sanitation resources. Not to sweep people off to some other block to face the fear of being swept again and again and again‚Ä¶

Things to bring:

-Signs demanding housing not sweeps

-Breakfast food or coffee

-Your voice and body to stand against inhumanity!@#

Stay tuned for updates if anything does go down today...

#HousingNotSweeps #MoveAlongToWhere??

Contact:

info@denverhomelessoutloud.org

720-940-5291

See More
item.author: Denver Action Network

item.title: On Saturday, July 25, a protest we organized to demand justice...
item.content:encoded:
Party for Socialism and Liberation - Denver

On Saturday, July 25, a protest we organized to demand justice for Elijah McClain was violently attacked by two white men who attempted to drive a Jeep through a crowd of hundreds of anti-racist protesters. The two men were not arrested, but instead were given assistance by police and let go. This attack was nothing less than white supremacist terrorism intended to halt the advance of the anti-racist struggle. Just as white supremacy resisted the advance towards equality duri...ng Reconstruction and the Civil Rights movement, so it does today. It is critical that in these moments, we stand together as a community and demonstrate our commitment to carrying forward the struggle against racism.

Join us August 30 for a march bringing together Denver and Aurora to demonstrate our unity and determination in the fight against racism and police violence. Attendees are invited to march on foot or in their cars. Please stay tuned for opportunities to volunteer and otherwise support this event. If you are a community leader or part of an organization that would like to endorse this demonstration, please message us!

Event page: https://facebook.com/events/351526215840428/

See More
